title: Biden, Capito Pursue Infrastructure Compromise
summary: White House says increase proposed by West Virginia's Shelley Moore Capito falls short of president's objectives. WASHINGTON-A Senate Republican leading efforts to reach a compromise on infrastructure legislation proposed a $50 billion spending increase from the latest GOP offer, a step that President Biden said fell short of what was necessary to reach an agreement.

title: Proposed Framework Aims to Guide Regulators in Decisions to Charge Chief Compliance Officers
summary: Proposal comes amid growing concerns over the individual liability of compliance professionals. A proposed framework guiding decisions to bring enforcement actions against financial sector chief compliance officers aims to address growing concern over the individual liability of compliance professionals.

title: Facebook Suspends Trump for Two Years
summary: Company said it would revisit decision two years from Jan. 7, the day after he urged his followers to go to Capitol as lawmakers were certifying Biden's win. Facebook Inc. said it is suspending Donald Trump's accounts for two years, formalizing a long-term penalty for the former U.S. president after its independent Oversight Board said the company was wrong to keep the ban open-ended.

title: AMC, Tesla, Zoom: Stocks That Defined the Week

title: Trump's Former White House Counsel Testifies on Capitol Hill
summary: Don McGahn appears in closed-door session of House Judiciary Committee on whether Trump obstructed justice. WASHINGTON-Former White House counsel Don McGahn testified Friday in a long-running Democrat-led congressional investigation into whether former President Donald Trump obstructed justice while in office.

title: A Good Worker Is Hard to Find
summary: The subsidies for not working continue to hurt the labor market.. Broad vaccine distribution and the end of government lockdowns should result in soaring job creation. Yet the U.S. labor market turned in its second disappointing result in a row in May, according to Friday's Labor Department report. That's what happens when government pays Americans not to work.

title: Facebook's New Trump Rules
summary: He's banned until 2023, and more political speech may be removed.. Facebook is trying, by progressive demand, to referee American politics, and the results aren't pretty. On Friday the social-media giant issued two new decisions-first, Donald Trump will remain banned from the platform until at least Jan. 7, 2023; and second, posts by politicians will be subject to more scrutiny by the company's censors.

title: The FBI Goes Postal
summary: A fishy news leak that the bureau is probing Louis DeJoy for long-ago campaign violations.. Stop us if you've heard this one. A leak to the Washington Post says the FBI is investigating a prominent GOP political figure who happens to be a target of Congressional Democrats. Hmmm.

title: Josh Hawley vs. Rahm Emanuel
summary: A dubious standard to bar the former mayor as envoy to Tokyo.. Josh Hawley doesn't think Rahm Emanuel is fit to serve as U.S. ambassador to Japan because he "clearly does not understand the China threat." The evidence? In an interview with the Washington Free Beacon, the Missouri Republican cited Mr. Emanuel's pursuit of Chinese investment as mayor of Chicago.

title: Microsoft's Bing Temporarily Blocked Searches of Tiananmen Square 'Tank Man' Image
summary: Company says 'accidental human error' caused problems with results for image linked to 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Beijing. Microsoft Corp.'s Bing search engine blocked content in the U.S. deemed politically sensitive to China's government on the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, a move the company said was an accident that it would correct.

title: Hiring Picked Up in May but Lagged Behind Broader Recovery
summary: U.S. employers added 559,000 jobs last month, amid signs that employers struggled to fill openings. U.S. employers boosted hiring in May, but not enough for the labor market to keep pace with an overall economy that is heating up as the pandemic continues to ease.

summary: S&P 500, meanwhile, hovers as investors parse signals about inflation and the labor market. Meme stocks are on the move again-while the broader market is running in place.

title: Breakup Meme From Elon Musk Sends Bitcoin Sliding
summary: Cryptocurrency prices drop amid concerns that Musk won't change his decision on suspending bitcoin as a form of payment for Tesla. Bitcoin, dogecoin and other cryptocurrencies skidded Friday, extending their monthlong rout, following another cryptic tweet from Elon Musk.

title: Supercomputer Embarks on Effort to Help Map the Universe, Dark Energy and All
summary: Researchers aim to create three-dimensional map by capturing light from more than 30 million galaxies and quasars. A national laboratory in California, armed with a powerful supercomputer, is set to create a highly detailed, three-dimensional map of the universe.

title: Why Biden Is Meeting With Putin
summary: Four U.S. presidents have found confronting the Russian leader more trouble than it's worth.. We don't have to imagine how the media would react if Donald Trump scheduled a summit with Vladimir Putin after a stream of Russian vandalism and insults against U.S. interests. Then again, the insults have been unending and presidents before Mr. Trump and Joe Biden conducted outreach to Mr. Putin near the start of their terms, in June (Messrs. Biden and Bush) or July (Messrs. Trump and Obama)

title: Crawfish Boils Land Rookies in Hot Water
summary: Resume Subscription. BRANCH, La.-As a rule, crawfish from the Frugé family farm never went far in life.

title: Clichés Set Off Alarm Bells
summary: I've started taking a hard look at common phrases.. 'Trust, but verify," President Reagan liked to say when I was coming of age in the 1980s. I swore I'd abide by his wisdom. How strange, then, to look up as a middle-aged man-an attorney, no less-and realize how many phrases in everyday life I've left utterly unexamined. This ends now.

title: Tax Incentives for Film Production? We've Seen This Movie Before
summary: When will state lawmakers learn that throwing money at Hollywood producers is a policy guaranteed to flop?. Call it the latest entry in the fantasy genre. As states look to bounce back from the economic damage of the coronavirus pandemic, many are considering new or expanded tax credits for movie production. The hope is that taxpayer subsidies will lure big-budget blockbusters and good-paying jobs, but such blatant corporate welfare has failed virtually everywhere it has been tried. It would be a comedy-if millions of dollars in taxpayer money weren't on the line.

title: Former Judge to Review Rudy Giuliani's Seized Materials
summary: Barbara Jones to examine materials seized in criminal investigation into former mayor's dealings with Ukrainian officials. A Manhattan federal judge Friday said he would appoint retired federal judge Barbara S. Jones to serve as the outside authority tasked with reviewing materials seized in a criminal investigation into Rudy Giuliani's dealings with Ukrainian officials.

title: Ackman SPAC Mystery Solved, but New Questions Abound
summary: Innovative and complicated structure of Universal Music deal isn't what investors expected. William Ackman ended one of the biggest guessing games on Wall Street by unveiling his $40 billion deal with Universal Music Group on Friday, but now a new one begins as investors puzzle over the transaction and the billionaire's next moves.

title: Biden Administration Moves to Restore Protections for Endangered Wildlife
summary: Safeguards for endangered animals and plants were loosened under the Trump administration. The Biden administration is moving to restore protections for endangered animals and plants that were loosened under former President Donald Trump, a move that had triggered lawsuits from environmental groups.

title: Abroad at Home: Into Cezanne's World
summary: Virtually visit the painter's studio, family estate and the sun-drenched sites elsewhere in Provence that inspired his work-like the majestic Mont Sainte-Victoire..

title: Trump Withdrawal Syndrome
summary: Media outlets like CNN and Facebook navigate the post-presidency.. Professional media folk couldn't live with former President Donald Trump's policies. Now they can't seem to live without him as a foil. Just as the press and the public health establishment are begrudgingly admitting that Mr. Trump's controversial theory that Covid-19 might have originated in a lab is plausible, a giant Silicon Valley publisher is formalizing a ban on contributions from the 45th president. The Journal's Paul Ziobro and Jeff Horwitz report:

title: The Dignity of Work
summary: Diego Rivera's 'The Flower Carrier' beautifully renders the daily strain of Mexico's indigenous laborers. The new San Francisco Museum of Art had recently opened on the fourth floor of the city's War Memorial Veterans Building with a tiny collection when, in March 1935, a founding trustee named Albert M. Bender wrote to his friend, the artist Diego Rivera, in Mexico City. Bender had donated 23 Rivera works on paper as part of his foundational gift and now, he said, the accession committee "would like one of your pictures." He asked Rivera to send him "a representation of your work at its finest and best" that Bender would then donate.

title: Stocks Close Near Records
summary: S&P 500 advances 0.9%, while meme stock craze continues. U.S. stocks rose Friday, posting modest weekly gains, after the monthly employment report showed the labor market continued its slow recovery in May.

title: Biden Ramps Up Fight Against Corruption
summary: Anticorruption push could lead to broader focus among federal prosecutors on corruption and bribery. President Biden is making anticorruption a central pillar of his administration's national security agenda, issuing a directive the White House said would help further collaboration between government agencies on issues including kleptocracy and illicit finance.

title: Aladdin (Saturday Crossword, June 5)

summary: JPMorgan says it won't give money to Republican lawmakers who questioned certifying Biden's win. WASHINGTON-Two major U.S. banks said they will resume campaign donations from their political-action committee, but split on the question about whether they would donate money to any of the 147 Republican lawmakers who voted to challenge the results of the 2020 election.

title: Fed Inching Toward Discussion of Slowing Bond Purchases
summary: May jobs report shows progress toward central bank goals, but a formal 'tapering' debate remains a ways off. WASHINGTON-Friday's jobs report keeps the Federal Reserve on track to begin informal internal discussions about reducing the pace of its large bond-buying programs, though a concrete plan for winding down the purchases isn't imminent.

title: Pentagon Envisions Using Cargo Rockets
summary: Commercial technology under consideration as way to make superfast deliveries to military hot spots. The Pentagon has revived plans to use commercial rockets such as those being developed by SpaceX to deliver supplies to military hot spots.

title: Putin Says the U.S. Wants to Hold Back Russia's Development
summary: In advance of a summit with Biden this month, the Russian leader called for improved relations with Washington. ST. PETERSBURG, Russia-Russian President Vladimir Putin said he would try to improve strained relations with the U.S. at his coming summit with President Biden and accused Washington of trying to stifle Russia's development.

title: Twitter's Operations Are Suspended in Nigeria
summary: Government action comes after social media giant suspended the president's account for a tweet the company said violated its policies. Nigeria has indefinitely suspended the operations of Twitter, the government said on Friday, two days after the social media giant suspended the account of the nation's president for a tweet warning of a return to violence in a civil war that cost millions of lives in the 1960s.

title: Joseph E. Yoakum's Spiritual Landscapes
summary: Starting in his 70s, the Chicago artist made visionary drawings of places seen and imagined. In the early 1960s, Joseph E. Yoakum was an elderly pensioner living in a storefront on Chicago's South Side, making drawings that he displayed on a clothesline in his window. By 1971, his work was hanging in the Museum of Modern Art-and in the homes of Chicago artists who, delighting in his densely layered landscapes, had helped bring him into the public eye.

title: Global Maritime Regulator Touts Contended Decarbonization Plan
summary: Amid global clamor for environmental action, International Maritime Organization plan would rate ships' 'carbon-intensity,' but set no specific emissions-reduction targets for at least two years. The head of the International Maritime Organization expects a key panel to adopt a blueprint on reducing carbon emissions at a meeting next week as the global marine regulator faces rising pressure from governments and from within its own ranks over environmental goals.

title: A Guide to San Diego's Best Beach Towns
summary: Five beach enclaves in San Diego's North County well worth exploring, with suggestions on where to surf, take long walks, eat alfresco and shop for one-of-a-kind keepsakes. Plus: Local surfer Danielle Black Lyons shares her favorite spots.. LEGOLAND, DISNEYLAND or La La Land. Visitors who head north from sunny San Diego are often aiming at a theme park or bigger city. Unless they're into surfing-in which case they're probably exploring the area's abundant breaks, which range from mellow rollers to high-powered tubes. But the string of coastal towns along San Diego's North County-from Del Mar to Oceanside-have much more to offer than surf, sun and rides. Each exudes its own particular vibe, from quirky to quietly high-design. If you're drawn to California farmer's markets, smoke-and-fire-themed restaurants, and contemporary galleries without a speck of cheesy beach-resort art, load up the Woody, with or without your boards inside. This southerly stretch of Highway 101 is worth a long weekend, at least.

title: Can the Next Mayor Make New York Safe Again?
summary: Rising crime is the city's biggest issue, but some Democratic candidates remain more worried about 'overpolicing.'. New York

title: Fauci Email Bolsters the Lab-Leak Theory
summary: A top scientist said the virus couldn't have evolved naturally-then reversed his position weeks later.. They told the world that the Covid-19 virus clearly couldn't have been manipulated in the laboratory. But what they actually thought at first sight was that it had been.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: Five books that illuminate the experience of D-Day, new fiction from Rivka Galchen, myth versus history at the Alamo, the Roman art of political humor and more..

title: Police Training Isn't the Only, or Main, Issue
summary: Violent crime is rising because of feckless and misguided leadership and legislation in America's large cities and states.. In "Defund the Police? No, Fund Them Better" (Declarations, May 29), Peggy Noonan misses the main reason that, as she correctly observes: "Violent crime is rising in almost every major American city, after decades of falling."

title: 'Forget the Alamo' Review: Legends of the Fall
summary: Can the Lone Star State's most famous story stand up to the gaze of history?. Growing up in San Antonio, I took Texas history in seventh grade, which has been required of all public-school students in the Lone Star State since 1946. Although we covered the entirety of the state's past, what I recall most vividly was the unit on the Texas Revolution. From our bee-hived teacher my classmates and I learned that the conflict between the rebellious Texans and the Mexican government in 1835-36 could be viewed in much the same way as the American Revolution: patriots resisting oppression by a haughty foreign power. She told us that the "Big Three" who perished in the Battle of the Alamo-Jim Bowie, William B. Travis and Davy Crockett-were martyrs for the cause of freedom, and that Santa Anna, the Mexican general who led the army that sacked the garrison and slaughtered all of its defenders, was evil incarnate.

title: The Problems With U.S. Ports Are Management's
summary: America's ports are extremely productive, with ILWU workers in California, Oregon and Washington breaking all-time records month after month during the pandemic.. Regarding Peter Tirschwell's "Behind Your Long Wait for Packages" (op-ed, June 3): America's ports are extremely productive, with International Longshore and Warehouse Union workers in California, Oregon and Washington breaking all-time records month after month during the pandemic. We risked our lives, losing some workers to Covid-19, to unload the PPE, medical equipment and other goods that have saved lives and stocked shelves. Our hard work has been praised and called "heroic" by port executives from Los Angeles to Seattle.

title: Five Best: D-Day Memoirs
summary: Selected by Peter Caddick-Adams, the author, most recently, of 'Sand and Steel: A New History of D-Day.'. By Mollie Panter-Downes Edited by William Shawn (1971)

title: U.S. UFO Report Doesn't Explain Mystery Sightings But Finds No Sign of Aliens
summary: Pilots have observed objects conducting maneuvers that would be impossible using known technology. WASHINGTON-A forthcoming U.S. intelligence report contains no evidence that unexplained objects moving through the skies and witnessed by U.S. Navy pilots are alien spacecraft, but offers no conclusive explanation for the mysterious sightings, according to people familiar with its contents.

title: The Inspirational Quest to Honor a Fallen Hero
summary: What an appropriate front page article for Memorial Day weekend.. True heroism manifests itself in many forms, and is so eloquently described in "One Last Mission: To Rescue a Fallen Marine's Purple Heart" (Page One, May 29). Among the obvious heroes are Lance Corporal Walter O'Haire, who made the ultimate sacrifice in serving his country, and Ben Kesling, who tirelessly led the effort to recover the Marine's missing medals and who wrote the inspiring story. But a person who stepped forward at a critical moment was the airline employee who initially refused to allow Mr. Kesling to board the plane with four carry-on items (as required by FAA and airline policy), but upon hearing his story simply responded, "You're good." Her grace and her instincts reflected true leadership when it might otherwise not have been expected.

title: L.A. Mansion With a TV Wall, a Car Showroom and a Half Basketball Court Sells for $44 Million
summary: Hedge-funder Jeffrey Feinberg bought the contemporary property from local spec developer Ramtin Ray Nosrati. Jeffrey Feinberg, a hedge-fund executive and a longtime basketball fan, has purchased a roughly $44 million newly built Los Angeles estate packed with sports-oriented amenities, according to the home's developer, Ramtin Ray Nosrati.

title: 'Until the World Shatters' Review: Mourning Myanmar
summary: Blessed with astonishing natural wealth, Myanmar once seemed on the verge of a revival and renaissance. No longer.. Pity Myanmar. Beautiful, yet long-suffering. Stocked with natural resources, yet dirt-poor. Appealing to tourists, yet beset by insurgencies and periods of authoritarian rule. Only a few years ago, the nation looked to be on the cusp of monumental change; NGOs and multinational firms spoke of "Myanmar's moment"-the twinning of a democratic opening and an economic renaissance. A 2013 McKinsey report ("Myanmar's Moment" was its title) said that the country might quadruple its economy in less than two decades.

title: China Reports First Human Case of H10N3 Bird-Flu Strain
summary: Chinese health authorities said a man contracted a rare strain of the virus. Chinese health authorities said a 41-year-old man had contracted a rare strain of bird flu known as H10N3 and had been in the hospital since late April, calling it the first reported human case globally from the strain. The National Health Commission said the man developed a fever and other symptoms on April 23 and was admitted to hospital in Jiangsu province five days later. On Tuesday the health commission said his condition was stable and indicated he was ready to be discharged.

title: Here's Why the Fed Isn't Frightened by the Jobs Report
summary: Jobs are hard to fill and wages are rising, but the Fed is weighing other factors that will dissuade it from raising rates for now. Employers are struggling to find workers, and that will push up labor costs, leading the Federal Reserve to raise rates much sooner than it expects to.

title: What Should You Keep in a Market Correction: Winning Stocks or Losers?
summary: The answer runs counter to what many investors might expect. With the stock market at or near record highs and so much good news baked into stock valuations, many investors are wondering whether we are due for a market correction. History has little to teach us there. Again and again, investors who try to time markets typically get it wrong.

title: Science Fiction: Sketches of Shannara
summary: For readers who have traveled deep into Terry Brooks's world, a glimpse of unseen territory.. Terry Brooks may well be the greatest beneficiary of the post-Tolkien boom in fantasy. His Shannara series, which began with "The Sword of Shannara" in 1977, now stretches to over two dozen volumes, not counting those in the "Landover" and "Word and Void" sequences.

title: 5 Box Wines Actually Worth Drinking: A Skeptic's Guide
summary: It's an undeniably convenient format, but the quality of the contents varies. Our wine columnist tasted her way through a lot of box wine to come up with a list of five best bets.. "LET'S OPEN a bottle of wine," I said to my husband recently. It was necessary to specify that I wanted wine in a bottle; we'd spent the last few weeks drinking wine that came from boxes.

title: FBI Director Compares Ransomware Challenge to 9/11
summary: Christopher Wray points to Russian hackers, calls for coordinated fight across U.S. society. FBI Director Christopher Wray said the agency was investigating about 100 different types of ransomware, many tracing back to hackers in Russia, and compared the current spate of cyberattacks with the challenge posed by the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

title: How to Take Your Start-Up Seriously but Not Personally
summary: The key is to use customer complaints as fuel for growth. Candace Nelson, a pastry chef and former investment banker, is co-founder of the cupcake bakery chain Sprinkles. She also is co-founder of CN2 Ventures, which invests in and incubates new business ventures.

title: The Underground Railroad Was No Fantasy
summary: The often-mythologized network that helped slaves escape to the North was America's first interracial mass movement. No aspect of American history has been more saturated with myth than the Underground Railroad. Television viewers have been mesmerized, and perhaps shocked, by the 10-part series "The Underground Railroad" on Amazon Prime, based on Colson Whitehead's 2016 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by the same name. Directed by Barry Jenkins, the series follows the odyssey of a young fugitive slave, Cora, through the grotesque cosmos of an America warped by antebellum slavery.

title: Sweetgreen Bet Big on Naomi Osaka. Then Doubled Down.
summary: Salad company backs tennis star's openness on mental health, retaining endorsement deal after she pulls out of French Open. Hours after Naomi Osakawithdrew from the French Open on Monday, the three founders of Sweetgreen Inc. gathered on a phone call.

title: U.S. Covid-19 Deaths Fall to Lowest Point Since March 2020
summary: As vaccinations rise, the seven-day average of reported deaths has dropped below 500. The average number of daily Covid-19 deaths in the U.S. has fallen to the lowest point in more than a year, a fresh sign that vaccinations are lessening the worst effects of the pandemic.

title: An Art-Filled Condo in Miami Beach
summary: This half-floor apartment in the Continuum features water views and a colorful art collection.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'Loot' Review: Plunder's Revenge
summary: A Victorian expedition gone wrong led to a mission of vengeance and the theft of a civilization's treasures.. In a forlorn corner of West Africa, the name of James Phillips resonates "like that of no other Englishman," writes Barnaby Phillips-no relation-in "Loot," an account of the plunder of a celebrated trove of tribal art. The art belonged to the Edo people, and Mr. Phillips tells the story of how it was taken, what happened to it, and whether it should be returned.

title: Miami Beach 'Sky Mansion' Sells for $30 Million Two Months After Hitting the Market
summary: The 8,229-square-foot apartment is the latest big-ticket sale at Ian Bruce Eichner's Continuum condo towers. A large apartment in a luxurious Miami Beach condo building has sold for $30 million roughly two months after coming on the market.

title: Thousands in Hong Kong Defy Police to Remember Tiananmen Victims
summary: Many turn out to mark anniversary of Tiananmen Square massacre; police arrest two, including senior activist. HONG KONG-Thousands of people in Hong Kong defied a huge police presence and threats of jail to commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, seeking to keep alive an annual vigil that has become an important symbol of opposition to China's continuing crackdown on freedoms in this former British colony.

title: 'Small World' Review: The Other Seamus
summary: Seamus Deane's imagination roamed from ancient Greece to 20th-century America-and always returned to Ireland.. When the Irish writer and critic Seamus Deane died last month in Dublin at the age of 81, some of the most striking tributes, among an international outpouring, were those paid by his former students. The Irish Times journalist Fintan O'Toole, for example, recalled a 1975 lecture at University College Dublin during which Deane "paced back and forth . . . smoking and talking as if in a trance, language flowing from him and carrying along on its tide a great freight of ideas and insights." And those of us fortunate enough to have attended such lectures have similar memories of what Mr. O'Toole describes as Deane's "very particular combination of reflection and combativeness."

title: To Offset Climate Change, Scientists Tout City Trees and Ultra-White Paint
summary: More trees and more reflective surfaces won't stop global warming, but they could help temper dangerous 'heat islands' in urban areas. Author

title: Consumers Try on Sexier Styles for a Post-Pandemic Summer
summary: Rent the Runway says use of crop tops, minis and pieces with cutouts is up this year. Recent reports by dating-app companies have indicated singles are ready to mingle this summer. Now it seems they are really baring it all.

title: 'How to Tell a Joke' Review: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum
summary: The Roman politician and orator Cicero used humor to charm audiences-and humiliate opponents.. In this elegant, smallish book, just slightly larger than the Loeb Classic Library volumes, with left-hand-pages given over to Latin text, editor Michael Fontaine, a professor of classics at Cornell University, combines the extant writings on humor in public speaking of Marcus Tullius Cicero (106-43 B.C.) and of Marcus Fabius Quintilianus (ca. A.D. 35-99). Mr. Fontaine calls Cicero's "On the Ideal Orator" a "masterpiece" and Quintilian's "The Education of the Orator" "a master textbook on public speaking." Neither is an understatement.

title: A Parisian Hôtel Particulier Revamped Into a Stylish Dream Home
summary: Alexandre de Betak has designed some of the fashion world's most iconic runway shows. Now he and his wife, Sofía, are focusing on their most personal project yet: their family's new home in Paris.. Alexandre de Betak, the 52-year-old designer behind some of the most viral fashion shows of the past 25 years, has staged runway spectacles in audacious locales. Through his Bureau Betak creative agency, he's conceptualized shows from Dior runways in Moscow's Red Square and under a 59-foot mountain of blue delphiniums custom built in the courtyard of the Louvre to a blue diamond catwalk inserted for Tiffany into Beijing's Forbidden City.

title: Cucumber Gazoz
summary: The cucumber syrup at the heart of this refreshing sparkler couldn't be easier to make, and it truly captures the dewy essence of the fruit. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: How the Class of 2021 Is Celebrating Commencement
summary: Some schools are holding in-person ceremonies at stadiums while others have opted for virtual celebrations. Schools have been setting their own practices and policies when it comes to graduation, and as a result, ceremonies are taking all forms.

title: 'Everyone Knows Your Mother Is a Witch' Review: Defending Her Life
summary: A woman is tried for witchcraft in a German city under the shadow of war and plague.. The Oxford English Dictionary tells me that the word "witch" entered the English language in the year 890, designating "a man who practices witchcraft or magic; a magician, sorcerer, wizard." It only took a century for the word to migrate over gender lines and settle elsewhere for good, becoming "a woman supposed to have dealings with the devil or evil spirits and to be able by their co-operation to perform supernatural acts." I don't think I need to say much about the cultural and political implications suggested by that transition. There are countless fictions centered on the idea of women whose evil originates in their dreadful power (Circe on her island, turning men to pigs), or on the horrifying conceit that some women might have power at all (the three witches who foretell Macbeth's doom). Most contemporary witch-driven narratives (a boggling count, Amazon assures) are romances with tinges of terror (the witch made lonely by power now looking for love) but there are also the more substantial, entertaining revisionist witches (J.K. Rowling's Hermione; Madeline Miller's take on Circe; Marvel's Wanda Maximov). High-art witch stories have tended to fare less well, the metaphorical potential of the material turning art into a civics class. Arthur Miller's play "The Crucible" is the worst of these, so clearly an allegory for Wrongful Persecution by the Powerful. It is almost tied for badness with John Updike's "The Witches of Eastwick," a satire of male power (creep undone by vengeful coven) that these days is hard not to read as a male fantasy about a four-way with a man in the middle.

title: Fiction: 'Dead Souls' Review
summary: A sardonic novel of poetry, plagiarism and literary politics that leans into its nihilism. In the more innocent year of 2012 the writer Elif Batuman posted the following tweet: "CHICHIKOV HAS 1,000,000 TWITTER FOLLOWERS. 999,985 OF THEM ARE DEAD." It was an excellent, if niche, joke, as Chichikov is the parvenu in Nikolai Gogol's classic novel who enters the ranks of Russian aristocracy by purchasing the souls of dead serfs. I intend no insult to the British poet Sam Riviere when I suggest that he has borrowed the gag (and Gogol's title) for his debut work of fiction, "Dead Souls" (Catapult, 291 pages, $26)-not only because the novel centers on a poet who has gained popularity by creating thousands of fake followers on a social-media app, but also because it is interested in the subjects of plagiarism and authenticity as they concern the arts under capitalism.

title: 'Double Blind' Review: Divided Selves
summary: The creator of Patrick Melrose returns with an up-to-the-minute satire on the age-old mind-body problem.. Edward St. Aubyn is best known for his darkly comic, psychologically penetrating five-book cycle- "Never Mind," "Bad News," "Some Hope," "Mother's Milk" and "At Last"-based unloosely on his own life. The books follow the socially privileged, emotionally damaged career of Patrick Melrose from the age of 5, when he was (first) raped by his father, through years of drug and alcohol addiction, recovery and relapse. The series ends 40 years after it began with Patrick, a divorced father of two, finding a sense of completion in the death of his mother. While this does sound grim, the novels are, for all that, fantastic comedies of manners and exercises in astringent irony.

title: Summer's Freshest Sparkling Drink Recipe
summary: A retro fizzy beverage is looking fresher than ever at Tel Aviv's Café Levinsky 41. The new book 'Gazoz' reveals the secrets of its effervescent architecture.. STROLL AROUND Levinsky Market in the Florentin neighborhood of Tel Aviv-among the Balkan delicatessens, Persian spice vendors, bureka stands, trendy bars and kitchen supply shops-and you will inevitably encounter fellow strollers sipping a sort of drink that might be mistaken for a floral arrangement.

title: Ackman's SPAC Deal to End All SPACs
summary: Buying 10% of Universal Music is just the warm-up act in hedge-fund billionaire William Ackman's deal ambitions, but he is over SPACs. Hedge-fund billionaire William Ackman launched the biggest-ever special-purpose acquisition company last year. Now his message is that SPACs have had their day.

title: Why Doing Good Is No Longer Bad Business
summary: The focus on environmental, social and governance changes at America's biggest companies is a response to demand from consumers and investors. It seems the modern corporate mission statement could use an update: Do well by doing good-or else.

title: Is Mexico's President a Threat to Its Democracy?
summary: Resume Subscription. During a recent visit to a coal-fired power plant run by Mexico's state electricity utility, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador recalled with nostalgia that only a few decades ago, the state produced all of the country's electricity. Now, he lamented, it generated only half, thanks to free-market policies over the past three decades that had hurt ordinary Mexicans. "In that period they tried to destroy Pemex and the Federal Electricity Commission with reforms to take market share away from them to give it to private companies, especially foreign ones," he said, referring to Mexico's former state oil and electricity monopolies.

title: We Tested 63 Red Lipsticks to Find the Best
summary: With many mask mandates lifting, it's time to take lips out of isolation and paint them a powerful red. One writer performed a sweeping red-lipstick trial to determine which ones are best equipped to wow during reopening.. RED LIPSTICK is intense, intimidating, sophisticated and infused with seductive symbolism. And yet, thanks to the myriad formulas available, anyone can pull it off. Even the most hesitant lipstick-wearer can find something that suits her tastes, whether that's a creamy version with rich blue undertones, a matte option with vivid orange notes or a moisturizing pink-tinged tube. I would know-I recently sampled 63 red lipsticks to find the best five on the market.

summary: Rebalancing can help retirees produce a stream of income from a diversified portfolio of stocks and bonds, and reduce risk. Here is something retirees ignore at their peril: Portfolio rebalancing, a simple technique that calls for periodically skimming profits from winners and plowing the proceeds into losers.

title: German Cardinal Offers Resignation Over Catholic Church's Sex-Abuse Failures
summary: Cardinal Reinhard Marx has played a leading role in the Vatican's financial overhaul and the German church's response to clerical sex abuse. Cardinal Reinhard Marx, a top adviser to Pope Francis and one of the most powerful figures in the German Catholic Church, offered the pope his resignation, saying he was taking responsibility for the church's institutional failures to prevent clerical sex abuse, his archdiocese said on Friday.

title: Why Does Anyone Care About a Superyacht?

title: You're Finally Going Back to the Office. What Are You Going to Wear?
summary: The rules about what to wear to the office are gone. Mattress maker ViscoSoft is relaxing its dress code as employees return to its Charlotte, N.C. headquarters in June. Instead of the button-down shirts and slacks that were the norm before the pandemic, staffers can now wear joggers, leggings and sweatshirts. "I told them no pajamas," said Chief Executive Gabriel Dungan.

title: Hamas Leader Courts Confrontation With Israel

title: Editor in Chief Kristina O'Neill on WSJ. Magazine's 2021 Summer Escapes Issue
summary: Resume Subscription. Sometimes the best way to keep a tradition alive is to spin it off in a new direction. That's how Honolulu, where veteran Tokyo chefs have settled down to incorporate local ingredients in their preparations, became one of the most exciting places in the U.S. to dine on sushi. A continuation of a wave of Japanese immigrants whose influence on Hawaii dates back to 1885, recent expats are not just opening restaurants and bars. Local artisans are brewing sake, distilling shochu and harvesting honey to make mead, all while bringing a spirit of small-scale craftsmanship to the Aloha State. It's made Oahu the place outside of Japan with the most vibrant expression of Japanese culture.

title: How WSJ. Magazine's Anubis and Bast Came to Be
summary: Anubis, Bast and Who, the adventurous creatures who were a beloved part of the WSJ. family for eight years via the editor's letter, are moving on from the magazine. Since the arrival of Editor in Chief Kristina O'Neill and the redesign that went into her first issue, in March 2013, WSJ.'s letter from the editor has been accompanied by hand-drawn, black-and-white illustrations featuring two characters inspired by the ancient Egyptian gods Anubis and Bast. Over the course of 99 issues, the pair has lived an enviable lifestyle: motorcycling through Laos, browsing London's Serpentine Pavilion, surfing in Maui-all while styled in the latest runway fashions.

title: The Most Super Supermoons Are Still to Come

title: Biden Signals Flexibility on Taxes for Infrastructure
